article.title: Uniform Silicon Isotope Ratios Across the Milky Way Galaxy

choices: Stellar density vs. Galactocentric radius
Stellar metallicity vs. Galactocentric radius
Oxygen isotope ratios vs. Galactocentric radius
Silicon isotope ratios vs. Galactocentric radius
The abundance of silicon monoxide increases towards the Galactic center.
The ratio of [¹⁸O]/[¹⁶O] increases towards the Galactic center.
The ratio of [¹⁷O]/[¹⁶O] decreases towards the Galactic center.
The abundance of oxygen increases towards the Galactic edge.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary takeaway from the data presented in Figure 3?
choices: Oxygen isotope ratios in the Galaxy defy predictions of closed-system GCE models.
Oxygen isotope ratios from young stellar objects are significantly different from those in molecular clouds.
Across the Galaxy, the [¹⁸O]/[¹⁶O] and [¹⁷O]/[¹⁶O] ratios define a slope in triple-isotope space consistent with closed-system GCE predictions.
The solar system has an anomalously low [¹⁷O]/[¹⁶O] ratio compared to the rest of the Galaxy.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 4 predict about the relative changes in oxygen and silicon isotope ratios as a function of stellar metallicity?
choices: Oxygen and silicon isotope ratios will vary in the same proportion as a function of stellar metallicity.
Oxygen isotope ratios will vary by a greater amount than silicon isotope ratios as a function of stellar metallicity.
Silicon isotope ratios will vary by a greater amount than oxygen isotope ratios as a function of stellar metallicity.
Oxygen and silicon isotope ratios will not vary as a function of stellar metallicity.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the slope of the best-fit line in Figure 5 indicate?
choices: A direct correlation between the formation age of presolar SiC grains and the surrounding metallicity.
An excess of ²⁸Si in presolar SiC grains compared to solar system values.
A higher ratio of [³⁰Si]/[²⁹Si] in presolar SiC grains compared to solar system values.
A lack of correlation between silicon isotope ratios and the ages of presolar SiC grains.
